dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Picture a massive eighteen-wheeler, just cruising down the 101 with no one in the driver's seat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Picture a massive eighteen-wheeler, just cruising down the one hundred one with no one in the driver's seat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, that's Waymo's test on June 16th—first unmanned truck on a public highway. That's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right, that's Waymo's test on June sixteenth-first unmanned truck on a public highway. That's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starsky Robotics, a San Francisco startup trying to commercialize automated truck technology, said its the first company to test an unmanned 18-wheeler on a stretch of U.S. highwayand it so by combining an onboard self-driving system with a remote operator standing by to guide the vehicle when necessary. Testing of a Volvo semi-truck loaded up with cameras and radar began June 16 on a 9.4-mile stretch of the Florida Turnpike in Orlando, connected to a Starsky teleoperations center in Jacksonville, said CEO and cofounder Stefan Seltz-Axmacher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they did it without any remote operators, which is a huge point of difference from companies like Starsky Robotics or TuSimple.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they did it without any remote operators, which is a huge point of difference from companies like Starsky Robotics or TuSimple.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starsky Robotics, a San Francisco startup trying to commercialize automated truck technology, said its the first company to test an unmanned 18-wheeler on a stretch of U.S. highwayand it so by combining an onboard self-driving system with a remote operator standing by to guide the vehicle when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, they're really betting on their onboard system handling everything, no human backup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, they're really betting on their onboard system handling everything, no human backup.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is risky, right? I mean, latency in cell signals could be a nightmare if something goes wrong mid-merge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is risky, right? I mean, latency in cell signals could be a nightmare if something goes wrong mid-merge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Competitors dont rely on remote operation, citing concerns about latency, the potential for delays in cell signal transmission.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. But their CEO, Stefan Seltz-Axmacher, seems confident—said it maintained 45 miles an hour, merged lanes, everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. But their C E O, Stefan Seltz-Axmacher, seems confident-said it maintained forty five miles an hour, merged lanes, everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The truck navigated a highway rest area, merged onto the Turnpike and changed lanes, maintaining an average speed of 55 miles an hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they're already making money from it? He mentioned they're pulling in around three hundred thousand dollars a month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're already making money from it? He mentioned they're pulling in around three hundred thousand dollars a month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Were in the neighborhood of half a million dollars a month, Seltz-Axmacher said, declining to comment on whether Starsky has additional fundraising plans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, from their conventional trucking operations too—helps fund the self-driving R&D. Smart move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, from their conventional trucking operations too-helps fund the self-driving R&D. Smart move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, its now generating revenue that helps fund ongoing development of its high-tech trucks, in addition to the $22 million its raised so far from initial investment rounds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus they've got sixty trucks in their fleet, half automated, half not. And ninety employees—half are actual drivers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus they've got sixty trucks in their fleet, half automated, half not. And ninety employees-half are actual drivers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has a fleet of 40 trucks, both automated and non-automated, and 80 employees, about half of whom are truck drivers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting how they're balancing the old school with the futuristic, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting how they're balancing the old school with the futuristic, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And while others are deep into remote operation setups with video game-like controls, Waymo's like, nah, we'll go solo.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And while others are deep into remote operation setups with video game-like controls, Waymo's like, nah, we'll go solo.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The remote operator sits in front of a bank of video monitors that show everything the trucks cameras see. Theres a small, video-game-style steering wheel, accelerator and brake pedals and other controls that let operators take over when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: High-risk, high-reward, I guess. But highway driving is simpler than city streets—no pedestrians, predictable patterns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: High-risk, high-reward, I guess. But highway driving is simpler than city streets-no pedestrians, predictable patterns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In part thats because highway driving is viewed as easier to master, owing to the absence of pedestrians, bicyclists and the complex intersections of urban streets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, taking the person completely out feels like a huge milestone. First time ever, he said.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, taking the person completely out feels like a huge milestone. First time ever, he said.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is literally the first time anyone has taken the person out of the vehicle on public highway, Seltz-Axmacher told Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder how soon we'll see these things hauling real freight cross-country, no humans involved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder how soon we'll see these things hauling real freight cross-country, no humans involved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Though I'd maybe want a remote operator on standby for, like… the first decade or so.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Though I'd maybe want a remote operator on standby for, like... the first decade or so.

artist_script:
HostA: Picture a massive eighteen-wheeler, just cruising down the 101 with no one in the driver's seat.
HostB: Oh, right, that's Waymo's test on June 16th—first unmanned truck on a public highway. That’s wild.
HostA: Yeah, and they did it without any remote operators, which is a huge point of difference from companies like Starsky Robotics or TuSimple.
HostB: Mhm, they’re really betting on their onboard system handling everything, no human backup.
HostA: Which is risky, right? I mean, latency in cell signals could be a nightmare if something goes wrong mid-merge.
HostB: For sure. But their CEO, Stefan Seltz-Axmacher, seems confident—said it maintained 45 miles an hour, merged lanes, everything.
HostA: And they’re already making money from it? He mentioned they're pulling in around three hundred thousand dollars a month.
HostB: Yeah, from their conventional trucking operations too—helps fund the self-driving R&D. Smart move.
HostA: Plus they’ve got sixty trucks in their fleet, half automated, half not. And ninety employees—half are actual drivers.
HostB: It’s interesting how they’re balancing the old school with the futuristic, you know?
HostA: Totally. And while others are deep into remote operation setups with video game-like controls, Waymo’s like, nah, we’ll go solo.
HostB: High-risk, high-reward, I guess. But highway driving is simpler than city streets—no pedestrians, predictable patterns.
HostA: Still, taking the person completely out feels like a huge milestone. First time ever, he said.
HostB: Makes you wonder how soon we’ll see these things hauling real freight cross-country, no humans involved.
HostA: Right? Though I’d maybe want a remote operator on standby for, like… the first decade or so.
